questions.question: What does the CREATE VIEW statement do?
options: Displays the structure of a table
Creates a virtual table based on a query
questions.answer: Creates a virtual table based on a query

questions.question: Which of the following is a correct syntax for creating a view?
options: CREATE VIEW view_name AS SELECT * FROM table_name;
questions.answer: CREATE VIEW view_name AS SELECT * FROM table_name;

questions.question: What is a view in MySQL?
options: A virtual table based on a SELECT query
questions.answer: A virtual table based on a SELECT query

questions.question: Which command retrieves data from a view?
questions.answer: SELECT * FROM view_name;

questions.question: Can views be queried like regular tables?
questions.answer: Yes

questions.question: Which of the following removes a view?
questions.answer: DROP VIEW view_name;

questions.question: What is the use of a view?
options: To restrict access to certain data
questions.answer: To restrict access to certain data

questions.question: What keyword is used to define a view?
questions.answer: CREATE

questions.question: Can you join tables in a view definition?
questions.answer: Yes

questions.question: Which of the following is true about views?
options: Views are always up-to-date with the underlying data
questions.answer: Views are always up-to-date with the underlying data

questions.question: Create a view of all employees in the Sales department.
options: CREATE VIEW sales_emps AS SELECT * FROM employees WHERE dept = 'Sales';
CREATE sales_emps VIEW SELECT employees WHERE dept = 'Sales';
SELECT * FROM employees WHERE dept = 'Sales' INTO sales_emps;
questions.answer: CREATE VIEW sales_emps AS SELECT * FROM employees WHERE dept = 'Sales';

questions.question: Select all records from a view named `recent_orders`.
questions.answer: SELECT * FROM recent_orders;

questions.question: Drop a view named `active_customers`.
questions.answer: DROP VIEW active_customers;

questions.question: Create a view to show name and salary from employees.
options: CREATE VIEW emp_info AS SELECT name, salary FROM employees;
CREATE emp_info VIEW SELECT name, salary FROM employees;
VIEW emp_info AS SELECT name, salary;
questions.answer: CREATE VIEW emp_info AS SELECT name, salary FROM employees;

questions.question: Create a view for orders above ₹10,000.
options: CREATE VIEW big_orders AS SELECT * FROM orders WHERE amount > 10000;
CREATE VIEW orders_big SELECT * WHERE amount > 10000;
CREATE big_orders AS SELECT * FROM orders WHERE amount > 10000;
VIEW big_orders AS SELECT * FROM orders WHERE amount > 10000;
questions.answer: CREATE VIEW big_orders AS SELECT * FROM orders WHERE amount > 10000;

questions.question: Create a view that joins customers and orders on customer_id.
options: CREATE VIEW cust_orders AS SELECT * FROM customers JOIN orders ON customers.id = orders.customer_id;
CREATE VIEW cust_orders FROM customers, orders WHERE id = customer_id;
VIEW cust_orders SELECT * JOIN customers orders;
questions.answer: CREATE VIEW cust_orders AS SELECT * FROM customers JOIN orders ON customers.id = orders.customer_id;

questions.question: Create a view showing only female employees.
options: CREATE VIEW female_emps AS SELECT * FROM employees WHERE gender = 'F';
questions.answer: CREATE VIEW female_emps AS SELECT * FROM employees WHERE gender = 'F';

questions.question: Create a view with only names from users.
options: CREATE VIEW user_names AS SELECT name FROM users;
SELECT name FROM users INTO user_names;
CREATE user_names AS SELECT name FROM users;
questions.answer: CREATE VIEW user_names AS SELECT name FROM users;

questions.question: Select data from view `high_scores` with score > 90.
questions.answer: SELECT * FROM high_scores WHERE score > 90;

questions.question: Create a view showing id and price from products table.
options: CREATE VIEW product_prices AS SELECT id, price FROM products;
CREATE product_prices AS SELECT id, price FROM products;
questions.answer: CREATE VIEW product_prices AS SELECT id, price FROM products;
